caption: Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.

result.explanation: The caption is factually incorrect. Jaden Smith did not commit suicide in July 2016.  The image shows Jaden Smith with Will Smith, but this fact is not present in the caption. The image does not provide any information to support the claim of suicide.

candidates.title: Jaden Smith Commits Suicide
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In July 2016, news raced through social media that Jaden Smith, actor and son of Will and Jada Pinkett-Smith, had committed suicide:
The news was not true, and didn't come from a legitimate source. In fact, users who clicked the above-displayed message were greeted with a popup message requesting permission from a Facebook app to post on their behalf, making the article appear less like a hoax and more like an outright scam:
Messages about Jaden Smith's alleged suicide were shared from various sites, and led to a variety of dodgy-sounding Facebook apps, including "Smart Mobiles," "Gadgy Land," "Pakiza," "Top Feeds" and several others.
Intrepid internet users who clicked the link and gave the app permission were eventually greeted with one of several "news" story claiming that Jaden Smith had committed suicide. The web sites responsible for this hoax have published dozens of fake news stories and graphics with this false claim:
Users who granted these apps permission to post to Facebook on their behalf quickly found this death hoax posted to their own Facebook feeds, thereby replicating itself across social media.
Jaden Smith himself has been active on his social media accounts, seemingly unaware that he's supposed to be dead. He posted a photograph of himself on 27 July 2016:
candidates.description: A hoax article reported that the actor (and teenaged son of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith) had killed himself.

result.explanation: The claim that actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016 is explicitly debunked by a fact-checking article from Snopes.com.  The article details how the news was a hoax spread through social media and involved fake Facebook apps designed to spread the false information. Jaden Smith himself was active on social media during that time, further discrediting the claim. Therefore, the news caption is definitively false.
result.supporting_points: Snopes.com article: "The news was not true, and didn't come from a legitimate source. ... Messages about Jaden Smith's alleged suicide were shared from various sites, and led to a variety of dodgy-sounding Facebook apps... Jaden Smith himself has been active on his social media accounts, seemingly unaware that he's supposed to be dead."

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external validation checks strongly indicate that the caption "Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016" is completely out of context and factually incorrect. The internal check identifies the factual inaccuracy and the lack of image support for the claim, assigning a confidence score of 0. The external check provides strong evidence from a reputable fact-checking source (Snopes.com) that debunks the suicide claim as a hoax, giving it a confidence score of 10.  There is no discrepancy between the two checks; they both definitively refute the caption's claim. The image itself shows Jaden Smith alive and well, alongside his father Will Smith, further supporting the falsity of the caption.  The high confidence score from the external check, combined with the internal check's confirmation of the factual error, leads to a final confidence score of 10. The caption is demonstrably false and bears no relation to the provided image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation methods strongly confirm that the caption is factually incorrect and completely out of context.  The claim of Jaden Smith's suicide is debunked by a reliable source, and the image itself contradicts the caption.
